headline.main: Antiviral Drugs Cut Flu Deaths, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Antiviral Drugs Cut Flu Deaths, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Tamiflu and its siblings reduced the mortality rate in hospitalized patients by as much as 50 percent, researchers say.
docs.snippet: Tamiflu and its siblings reduced the mortality rate in hospitalized patients by as much as 50 percent, researchers say.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Lester Minto knows he won't be able to reopen his clinic after a federal appeals court upheld tough new abortion restrictions in Texas. But he insists he won't be silenced.

headline.main: Court Hands Setback to Texas Abortion Law Critics
headline.print_headline: Court Hands Setback to Texas Abortion Law Critics

docs.snippet: Dr. Lester Minto knows he won't be able to reopen his clinic after a federal appeals court upheld tough new abortion restrictions in Texas. But he insists he won't be silenced.

headline.main: The Dollar Value of an Extra Year of Life

docs.abstract: The cost of a new treatment for hepatitis C has renewed a debate about drug prices and whether its cost exceeds the price society is willing to pay, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: The cost of a new treatment for hepatitis C has renewed a debate about drug prices and whether its cost exceeds the price society is willing to pay, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: A law set to go into effect next Tuesday would impose the strictest rules in the country over the use of medication to induce abortions during the early stages of pregnancy.

headline.main: Court Weighs Delay of Strict Limits to Drug-Induced Abortions in Arizona
headline.print_headline: Court Weighs Delay of Strict Limits to Drug-Induced Abortions in Arizona

docs.abstract: Federal Judge David C Bury weighs arguments over Arizona law set to go in effect that would impose the strictest rules in the country over the use of medication to induce abortions during the early stages of pregnancy.
docs.snippet: A law set to go into effect next Tuesday would impose the strictest rules in the country over the use of medication to induce abortions during the early stages of pregnancy.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study shows that affluent counties have experienced the biggest declines in smoking rates, while progress in the poorest ones has stagnated.

headline.main: Smoking Proves Hard to Shake Among the Poor
headline.print_headline: In a New Divide, Smoking Is Becoming a Habit of the Poor

docs.abstract: Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation analysis of federal data shows that smoking is increasingly becoming habit of poor Americans; study shows affluent counties have experienced biggest declines in smoking rates, while progress in poorest ones has stagnated.
docs.snippet: A new study shows that affluent counties have experienced the biggest declines in smoking rates, while progress in the poorest ones has stagnated.

byline.contributor: Sabrina Tavernise reported from Manchester, and Robert Gebeloff from New York.
byline.original: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and ROBERT GEBELOFF

docs.lead_paragraph: National Football League commissioner Roger Goodell said he was waiting for all the facts to emerge before deciding whether to punish Indianapolis Colts owner Jim Irsay for his recent arrest on suspicion of intoxicated driving.

headline.main: Goodell Says Colts Owner Irsay May Face Punishment
headline.print_headline: Goodell Says Colts Owner Irsay May Face Punishment

docs.snippet: National Football League commissioner Roger Goodell said he was waiting for all the facts to emerge before deciding whether to punish Indianapolis Colts owner Jim Irsay for his recent arrest on suspicion of intoxicated driving.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court should reject the claim of religious infringement in the health care law’s contraception mandate.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that the Supreme Court should reject the claim of religious infringement in the health care law's contraception mandate, which has been made by corporations Hobby Lobby and Conestoga Wood Specialties; warns of the ripple effects should the court find in the companies' favor.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court should reject the claim of religious infringement in the health care law’s contraception mandate.
